title: Niko Lusiani
text:
Niko Lusiani is a strategist, researcher and policy advocate with 20 years of experience in economic policy and corporate finance research and a proven record of influencing business behavior, mobilizing major investors, and securing legislative, regulatory and public policy wins.
As Research Director on Climate & Energy at the Rainforest Action Network, he leads the organization’s investigations into the energy sector, specifically the role of financial institutions and insurance companies in enabling harmful fossil fuel projects. Former Director at the Roosevelt Institute, Senior Advisor at Oxfam America’s private sector team and Director of Economic Policy at the Center for Economic and Social Rights, Niko is adept in managing cross-cultural and multilingual teams, mentoring emerging leaders, and conducting creative interdisciplinary research that shapes national and global debates.
His research and advocacy have influenced the White House, US Congressional leaders, antitrust and securities regulators, major asset managers, UN negotiators and the US Supreme Court. His work has received extensive coverage in top-tier media outlets, such as the New York Times, Financial Times and Bloomberg.
You can find his bio, a list of his publications and media appearances across this website.

title: About
text:
Nicholas (Niko) Lusiani is an internationally recognized expert, known for his incisive research, public thought leadership, and policy impact in the fields of corporate governance, tax, finance, and inequality. With two decades of experience across think tanks, NGOs, and grassroots organizations, Niko brings analytical rigor, a deep aptitude for coalition-building and a strategic vision for systems change.
As Research Director on Climate and Energy at the Rainforest Action Network, he leads the organization’s investigations into the energy sector, specifically the role of financial institutions and insurance companies in enabling harmful fossil fuel projects. Previously at the Roosevelt Institute, he led pioneering work on corporate taxation, inflation and market power, and the clean energy transition-—shaping public discourse through regular commentary in outlets like the Financial Times, Bloomberg, TaxNotes and ABC News. A prolific and ambidextrous author, his writing spans peer-reviewed academic publications, policy briefs, articles and op-eds. Niko is currently writing his first book on the public origins of corporate value.
Throughout his career - including senior roles at Oxfam and the Center for Economic and Social Rights - Niko’s unique fluency across academic, policy, and media arenas has enabled him to drive narrative change while also securing tangible legal, regulatory and legislative victories. His cutting-edge applied research helped shift U.S. government stances on vaccine equity, shaped the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights and UN Sustainable Development Goals, and informed new global tax reporting standards, FASB accounting standards and SEC disclosures. His research also helped protect tax equity at the US Supreme Court.
Multilingual and globally engaged, Niko is an alum of UCLA and Columbia University’s School of International and Public Affairs. Raised by his amazing mother in northern California, he now lives in Takoma Park, Maryland with his wife, two children, and furry friends: his tabby cat, Loki and his bernedoodle, Archie.
